docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are increasingly gloomy about the costs and quality of their health care if Congress passes overhaul legislation, according to the latest USA Today/Gallup poll. The survey results underscore the political challenges for supporters of a health care overhaul, as few Americans see benefits for themselves in changing the system.
docs.abstract: USA Today/Gallup poll finds that Americans are increasingly gloomy about costs and quality of their health care if Congress passes overhaul legislation; results underscore political challenges of health care reform, as few Americans see benefits for themselves in changing system (M)
docs.snippet: Americans are increasingly gloomy about the costs and quality of their health care if Congress passes overhaul  legislation, according to the latest USA Today/Gallup poll.     The survey results underscore the political challenges for supporters of a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Remember when drug makers, hospitals, doctors and medical device manufacturers stood by President Obama earlier this year and pledged to cut $2 trillion in health costs over the next decade? A nonpartisan coalition of business, labor and religious groups has a message for Congress: write that promise into law. In a report issued Thursday, the National Coalition on Health Care called on Congress to write a trigger mechanism into any health care overhaul that would enforce savings through regulation if industry failed to live up to its promises after a set period.
docs.abstract: National Coalition on Health Care issues report calling on Congress to write trigger mechanism into any health care overhaul that would enforce savings through regulation if industry failed to live up to its promises after set period; nonpartisan coalition warns that health care system was projected to waste $10 trillion over decade, and argues that cutting even small fraction of waste could easily pay for cost of covering uninsured (M)
docs.snippet: Remember when drug makers, hospitals, doctors and medical device manufacturers stood by President Obama earlier this year and pledged to cut $2 trillion in health costs over the next decade? A nonpartisan coalition of business, labor and religious...

docs.lead_paragraph: Barbara Ehrenreich is now the latest to weigh in on the Female Happiness Conundrum - the whole cultural brouhaha caused by the news from Wharton School professors Betsey Stevenson and Justin Wolfers earlier this year that despite all the objective improvements to their lives over the past four decades, women today appear to be less happy than they were in 1972.

headline.main: When We're Equal, We'll Be Happy

docs.abstract: Why aren't women happier? Because there are still too many obstacles to equality.
docs.snippet: Why aren't women happier? Because there are still too many obstacles to equality.

docs.lead_paragraph: While Senate Democrats continue to hem and haw about whether they will include a government-run insurance plan in their health care legislation, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, said on Thursday that there are no such doubts on her side of the Capitol.

headline.main: Pelosi: House Firm in Backing Public Option

docs.abstract: While the Senate considers the fate of government-run insurance, the House remains committed to it.
docs.snippet: While the Senate considers the fate of government-run insurance, the House remains committed to it.

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a week of deliberations, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, is leaning toward including a government-run insurance plan in a health care bill he will soon take to the Senate floor, Democratic senators said Thursday.

headline.main: Senate Majority Leader Reid Leaning Toward 'Public Option' for Insurance

docs.abstract: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, is leaning toward including a government-run health insurance plan in a health care bill he will soon take to the Senate floor, Democratic senators said Thursday.
docs.snippet: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, is leaning toward including a government-run health insurance plan in a health care bill he will soon take to the Senate floor, Democratic senators said Thursday.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are increasingly gloomy about the costs and quality of their health care if Congress passes health care legislation, according to the latest USA Today/Gallup poll.

headline.main: Public Gloomier About Cost and Quality of Health Care if Congress Enacts an Overhaul

docs.abstract: Americans are increasingly gloomy about the costs and quality of their health care if Congress passes health care legislation, according to the latest USA Today/Gallup pol.
docs.snippet: Americans are increasingly gloomy about the costs and quality of their health care if Congress passes health care legislation, according to the latest USA Today/Gallup pol.

docs.lead_paragraph: Steve Benen gets exercised over a new appearance of a zombie lie in the health care debate -- the totally false claim that Canadian health care won't pay for hip replacements for the elderly.
docs.abstract: Who pays for hip replacements in America? Medicare.
docs.snippet: Who pays for hip replacements in America? Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: In The New York Times today, my colleague Robert Pear and I said that Democrats "lost a big test vote on health care legislation" when the Senate blocked action on a bill to increase Medicare payments to doctors at a cost of $247 billion over 10 years.

headline.main: Day After: Fallout From 'Doc Fix' Vote

docs.abstract: What does the "doc fix" vote portend for health care legislation in the Senate?
docs.snippet: What does the "doc fix" vote portend for health care legislation in the Senate?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration will take a hacksaw to executive compensation at the companies that received the most federal bailout money. For the 25 top earners at seven companies that received exceptional help -- Citigroup, Bank of America, American International Group, General Motors, Chrysler and the financing arms of the two automakers -- the order will cut the cash portion their salaries by about 90 percent and their total compensation by about 50 percent on average. The Federal Reserve, acting separately on Thursday, proposed to review the pay practices of the nation's largest banks.

headline.main: The Fallout From Big Pay Cuts

docs.abstract: Will the federal order to cut executive pay at bailed-out firms have long-term consequences?
docs.snippet: Will the federal order to cut executive pay at bailed-out firms have long-term consequences?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group, has just come out with a new analysis of the proposed Cadillac tax on expensive health insurance plans. That proposal -- part of the Senate Finance Committee's version of health reform -- has attracted a lot of criticism from the left, especially from labor unions.
docs.abstract: A new report argues that liberals should like proposals for a so-called "Cadillac tax" on expensive health insurance plans.
docs.snippet: A new report argues that liberals should like proposals for a so-called "Cadillac tax" on expensive health insurance plans.
